results.title: Shirley McKechnie
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dance: Videos of Australian dancers and choreographers”.
Shirley McKechnie trained in the Bodenweiser technique with Hanny Kolm and Daisy Pirnitzer. McKechnie speaks about her formative years and her desire to develop a philosophy of art and, through that, a philosophy of life. McKechnie started the “Contemporary Dance Theatre of Melbourne” with a group of her students and together they explored a range of techniques in order to develop a style relevant to the Australian experience. McKechnie played a pivotal role in establishing dance training at a tertiary level in Australia and was a co-founder of the “Australian Association of Dance Education”. McKechnie recalls her relationship with Dame Peggy van Praagh and their shared desire to develop the intellectual ability of dance artists. Through her involvement with education departments, arts organisations and performing companies, McKechnie has had a profound influence on the direction of dance training in Australia. Researched and interviewed by James Murdoch.

group.title: Dance: Videos of Australian dancers and choreographers

results.title: Margaret Evelyn Walker
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dance: Videos of Australian dancers and choreographers”.
Margaret Evelyn Walker is one of the best loved figures in dance in Australia. She discusses her travels in Eastern Europe in the 1940’s and 1950’s, her belief in the power of folk music, her struggles to have it accepted as a subject in schools and of the establishment of the Australian Association for Dance Education. Interview conducted by James Murdoch.

group.title: Dance: Videos of Australian dancers and choreographers

results.title: Laurel Martyn
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dance: Videos of Australian dancers and choreographers”.
Laurel Martyn trained in London with Phyllis Bedells and was awarded a choreographic scholarship under the auspices of Ninette de Valois. In this interview, Martyn recalls the highlights of her performing career with the “Sadler’s Wells Ballet” in England and the “Borovansky Ballet” in Australia and discusses her teaching method and philosophy. Through her company, “Ballet Vistoria”, Martyn encouraged the development of a distinctively Australian style of dance and introduced ballet to thousands of school children. Researched and interviewed by James Murdoch.

results.title: Last man hanged
results.brief_description: This dramatised documentary depicts the events leading up to the hanging of Ronald Ryan in Pentridge Gaol in 1967 - the last man hanged in Australia. Through the eyes of Keith Willey (Lewis Fitz-Gerald), the journalist who followed the case, we see Ryan as a complex man who was as much a victim as those he had violated. This documentary details how the State Premier, Sir Henry Bolte, facing an imminent election, decided to make an issue of the case and pushed through the hanging despite nationwide protest. What evolves is powerful and emotional statement about capital punishment.

results.title: The Ten Commandments
results.creator_credit: Cecil B. DeMille and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Cecil B. DeMille’s classic Biblical epic, with a galaxy of stars led by Charlton Heston as Moses and Yul Brynner as Pharoah. It is the story of the life of Moses from birth and abandonment through manhood, slavery and the trials of turning his back on a privileged life in the Pharoah’s household and leading his people, the Jews out of Egypt and to freedom. Filmed in Egypt and the Sinai with one of the biggest sets ever constructed for a motion picture, this is a unique and motion picture experience with the parting of the Red Sea and the writing of the tablets being unforgettable highlights. Oscar winning special effects.

constellations_other.name: Divining the divine
constellations_other.description: Depicting the Almighty in paintings was frowned upon in the early 1800s in Britain, much like it has been throughout the history of cinema, according to writer Scot Hughes, who made many of these connections in a 2003 article in the Sydney Morning Herald.

results.title: From little things big things grow: Kev Carmody, singer
results.creator_credit: Trevor Graham, Ned Lander, Rachel Perkins and City Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blood brothers (A)”.
Interspersed with video clips from his protest album “Pillars of society” Kev Carmody talks about his life and music. Born in Goronba, Queensland, on a cattle station, the son of an Irish stockman and his Aboriginal wife, Carmody spent his early years living off the land, but absorbing western culture through the ABC and old records. Taken away from his parents at the age of ten, he was put in a Christian school and sent home twice a year. After several years working at various menial jobs, whilst developing his music he eventually gained a Ph.D in Australian history, using oral material and methods rather than a written thesis. A fascinating portrait of a committed man.

results.title: Discovering the Murray-Darling Basin
results.creator_credit: Kenyon Castle, Kenyon Castle Productions and Murray-Darling Basin Commission (Australia)
results.brief_description: Mike Hayes presents this video which shows the immense variety of Australia’s most important agricultural region, stretching from Queensland to South Australia. Not only is the area important agriculturally, but it is also an area of great beauty, rich in wildlife, history and folk lore. Produced for the Murray-Darling Basin Commission the program stresses that almost everybody in Australia is dependent in some way on this vast area and that therefore we should be working to prevent further degradation and repair some of the damage which has already been done.

results.title: All that is solid
results.brief_description: This is a speculative documentary on the subject of the future of Australia. It is conceived as a series of competing discourses with visionaries, politicians, media commentators and others, who are variously optimistic and pessimistic. Interviews are interspersed with symbolic, imaginative drama.

results.title: Scripture for a smoke screen: Episode 1 – dolphin house
results.creator_credit: Amrita Hepi, Luke Smith and Zoe Theodore
results.brief_description:
“I’m interested in exploring the gulf between lived experience and its representation, and how identity and ideas around intelligence are constantly being shaped, amplified or flattened through the experience of surveillance and misidentification.”

In the 1960s, scientists tried to talk to dolphins. The experiment was backed by NASA, who were investigating ways to communicate with extra-terrestrial life. One intelligence test attempted to determine self-awareness by seeing if the dolphins recognised themselves in a mirror.

Amrita Hepi draws on that trial in “Scripture for a smokescreen: Episode 1 – dolphin house”, seemingly seducing her own image. She dances with an inflatable dolphin, attempting to communicate with it through voice and movement, paralleling the intimacy between one of the researchers, Margaret Lovatt, and a male dolphin during the experiment.

Not only does Amrita lampoon the absurdity of teaching marine mammals English, she uses the study to expose the way Western knowledge systems – language, ethics and science – are imposed on people and cultures through colonisation. Through choreographed dance and moving image, Amrita explores what happens when we’re constantly under surveillance, and when assumptions about us are presented to the world through someone else’s viewpoint.

Amrita Hepi is represented by Anna Schwartz Gallery

constellations_primary.name: Scripture for spiritual connections and sci-fi futures
constellations_primary.description: Connections between people, animals and the environment in sci-fi stories, videogames, art and film.

results.description:
“I’m interested in exploring the gulf between lived experience and its representation, and how identity and ideas around intelligence are constantly being shaped, amplified or flattened through the experience of surveillance and misidentification.”

In the 1960s, scientists tried to talk to dolphins. The experiment was backed by NASA, who were investigating ways to communicate with extra-terrestrial life. One intelligence test attempted to determine self-awareness by seeing if the dolphins recognised themselves in a mirror.

Amrita Hepi draws on that trial in Scripture for a smokescreen: Episode 1 – dolphin house, seemingly seducing her own image. She dances with an inflatable dolphin, attempting to communicate with it through voice and movement, paralleling the intimacy between one of the researchers, Margaret Lovatt, and a male dolphin, Peter, during the experiment.

Not only does Amrita lampoon the absurdity of teaching marine mammals English, she uses the study to expose the way Western knowledge systems – language, ethics and science – are imposed on people and cultures through colonisation. Through choreographed dance and moving image, Amrita explores what happens when we’re constantly under surveillance, and when assumptions about us are presented to the world through someone else’s viewpoint.

Amrita Hepi is represented by Anna Schwartz Gallery
